Well executed platform puzzler that starts out deceptively easy and gets harder, very much harder, the further you progress. Don't be put off by the childlike cartoony and colorful graphics or the fact that it involves a young chick - named Toki Tori - and his search and rescue mission for his younger brothers and sisters who are still in their eggs.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=345021358
Yes - it sounds like something you would give a young child to play and whilst they will certainly get much delight out of the game during its earlier levels the game will certainly require some flexing of the old grey matter if you plan on getting through the levels on the harder difficulties. Much trial and error will be required to master some of these devilishly cunning levels.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=345021975
Originally released as a game for the Gameboy color back in the early 2000's, Toki Tori benefits wonderfully from an HD upgrade for modern computers. Brilliant level design combined with charming visuals makes this a must-have for puzzle enthusiasts and is the perfect family game to play with the young ones in tow.

- Some instructions could be a little more precise to be correct (in case young kids are playing this), but no problem.
- Non-puzzle levels as transition between worlds is a nice artistic touch.
- The wildcard is an awesome feature. You can use it to skip a tricky level, and if you need it later, you can unlock it again by completing the level you used it on. I understand that it is useful to them for getting feedback from people, but it should be a free decision, and not incentivized through content. At the time of writing this it's 90% off, and there's even a demo available. Easy decision.

reviewText:
This is a puzzle game that looks cartoonish and plays like it would be for very young players ---- and I suppose it could be, but the various levels get extremely difficult as you progress so maybe those levels are for more experienced players.
I'm just not sure if the devs are aiming at a universal audience or not.

But at its heart it is a puzzle game that will require the thinking cap. It features very short levels that are connected only by the fact that the goal is the same in each ---- collect the designated number of eggs within the level. There is no story involved, just get the eggs and move on to the next level.
And that's ok, but after a while it gets a bit boring, for me.
To add to this, the game's pace is super slow. The main character moves slow, and the few enemies I've seen are slow.

The game reminds me of those Super Granny games where she is rescuing her cats ---- in slow motion with no story.

There are many who will see a good amount of appeal here, and the price is good (especially if on sale), so if you find cute, bright, colorful, and very challenging puzzle games to your liking you should check this one out.
Very hard to decide whether to click yes or no on this one ---- but since we all have different tastes in games, I'll recommend it, with reservations, because it's not one that I would personally spend more time with. Maybe the kids.

reviewText:
Does anyone here remember the PC game Lemmings? You'd get a constant flow of cute little pixely critters, often upwards of 50 of them, and you'd have to guide them to an exit by designating them special skills like digging of floating or exploding. In the end you had to rescue only a set number of Lemmings, and as a result you often had room for error that let you experiment a little at finding a unique solution and have a mini-panic when you accidentally lead half of them off a cliff.

Toki Tori reminds me of this game that I have a lot of nostalgia for because it brings to mind the levels where you'd only have one lemming, and there really only was one solution that didn't involve the cathartic nuke button. By about a fourth of the way through this game, the levels take a turn towards complexity so baffling that you will have no room for error and no ability to predict what tools you might need to save for later.

Don't get me wrong, the game is cute and entertaining, but it is far too shallow. Frustration with the invariably complicated one and only solutions lead me to use a walkthrough for most of the second half of the game. Each time I'd wonder aloud How was I supposed to figure that one out?". I later found out that there is an (undocumented I think?) feature allowing you to zoom out enough to more carefully study the level and predict what you'll need. That would have helped a little earlier
date: but I still probably would have resorted to drawing out the level and spending 30 minutes working out the solution on paper. Maybe Toki Tori 2 has improved on the difficulty curve
recommended: or on the general boredom that results from the uninspiring puzzle design. I wouldn't know as I'm not willing to risk the amount of money it costs.\n\nTwo Tribes has made better. EDGE is a personal favorite of mine. But Toki Tori is just a bit too unforgiving for me to enjoy it
hoursPlayed: and as such I cannot recommend it."

reviewText:
Presentation
This little bird first saw the light of day back in 2001 on the good old Game Boy Color, but it manages to remain entertaining and relevant to this date thanks to HD versions, remakes and the fact that you can get it on almost any possible platform including the PC. So, what makes it fun to play 13 years later? Maybe it's the fact that it looks cute and childish and somehow reminds us of a time when games were made for fun and this is certainly an easy to learn, hard to master kind of game because it looks simple at first, but you'll often find yourself looking for the answer somewhere else as you'll get stuck more often than you'd think. The story is simple and just like in Angry Birds you are supposed to rescue your lost brothers, which come in the form of eggs, and not actual birds, but you'll have to go through quite a lot to achieve that. The menu is simple and intuitive and choosing what level you want to play once you unlocked the hard and bonus levels is easy to do, so you won't find yourself navigating the menus in order to find something because all you need is always one click away.
Rating: 8

Gameplay
The gameplay in Toki Tori is as simple as it gets as you can move left/right/up/down using the mouse to point the next place you want your little bird to go and use items in order to pass a certain obstacle or defeat your enemies such as worms, ghosts or porcupines; such items include a freeze gun, a vacuum, instant rocks or the ability to teleport or create bridges. The PC version also has a option to rewind, so in case you screw up you can always go back a couple of seconds and try again which will reduce your frustration because sometimes you might press the wrong button and use an item instead of another or make a wrong step near the end and playing the whole level again would drive you mad. The only thing missing was the ability to jump as I always tried to jump thinking that it would make the whole puzzle easier to solve, only to remember that I can't do that, but either way it's not so bad because you don't really need to as the items and abilities are more than enough.
Rating: 9

Graphics
This game looks good as it has a nice pallet of colours and it has that childish look that will make you nostalgic as it is one of those games that will age very well in the purest Nintendo style. Each stage has its own theme so when you will find yourself in the sewers the level design will make it feel like unique and different from the previous stages and the little details like the mud interacting with Toki's feet are going to display the level of attention this game got from the developers and it really shows that they wanted to deliver a better experience with this release and not make it look like just another HD remake.
Rating: 9

Audio
Toki Tori sounds just as good as it looks as the sound manages to deliver the same thing: a childish experience that will stay with you for a long time, and while it repeats the same music over and over again in the menu it never feels overused and during the actual levels the sound manages to deliver the same experience the design does and this helps the player's immersion. The sound effects are also okay, nothing will take you out of this magical world where a chick fights ghosts and worms.
Rating: 9

Extras
The PC version comes with some exclusive levels and the ability to rewind, but the real win comes with the level editor which allows you to create your own unique adventures and challenges for the little bird and thanks to Steam you are able to share them with your friends. The Steam Achievements are also a nice incentive to make you play again certain levels and thanks to all that I managed to spend more time in Toki Tori than in some big triple A games out there.
Rating: 10

Verdict
Toki Tori is a cheap and fun game and no matter if you're getting at full price or grabbing your copy during the next sale, Toki Tori is need to buy because it will take you by surprise regarding how much you will enjoy it no matter if you like that type of games or not and even if you go in to play just a level you will end up spending hours in it and for such a small price it's clearly a bargain.
Rating Overall: 9

reviewText:
Toki Tori is a puzzle game by Two Tribes[www.twotribes.com], released in January 2010. You play the game as a chick by the name of Toki Tori, who is on a quest to collect all the eggs in the world. The game is divided into five worlds, who are also divided into several levels. To proceed into the next level, the player has to collect all the eggs in one level. By proceeding through the game, the player unlocks different tools, which he needs in order to reach certain eggs, but every level has a limited amount of tool uses and this is where the tricky part comes in.

If you are familiar with puzzle games, the game will probably not be very challenging and if you aren't, it's still very easy in the beginning, but gets very hard in the end. The levels are monotone and once you get the hang of one level, you can project that procedure to other levels.

The game gets quite hard in the end and the monotony that I was talking about is compensated by the different worlds in the game, which all have very different themes and different tools. The atmosphere is happy and joyful in the first world, but soon turns darker and more dangerous as more enemies and traps appear. The game features adorable colorful comic graphics and a cheering and catchy music.

Toki Tori is overall a lovely game if you want to pass the time or if you just want a casual game that cheers you up. It's great for people who don't want a serious game and it's a must-have for every puzzle game lover.

reviewText:
Toki Tori is an eggcellent and hard-as-eggs puzzle game. Do not be fooled by its cutesy look, for underneath it lies very solid gameplay and clever level design.

The goal of each level is to collect all eggs using a limited number of items available at your disposal. Some levels have enemies you need to circumvent, but usually the main problem becomes planning your way through the level and finding the right order in which to collect all the eggs. Toki Tori has this peculiar puzzle game quality that often makes you think “this level is impossible, the game must be bugged!” in frustration and despair until you finally stumble upon the unexpected solution and marvel at how you couldn't think of it earlier.

Despite its appearance, the game is NOT a platformer. Toki Tori has no inertia and can neither jump nor dash. All characters and objects in the game are always “snapped” to a large grid, which saves you from that awful mentality of trying to find a pixel-perfect location for a block to place. After having learned the game mechanics, you’ll soon find yourself able to plan your way throughout the entire level without any prior experimentation. The game does, however, feature a convenient time rewind function that lets you try your idea and, if you see it fail, rewind it back.

If you’re unsure, I dare you to try the demo and see if you can resist Toki Tori's cuteness and wit.

This is basically a 2d platformer, but you can't make the character to jump and slash enemies. Instead, you're given the options to put a block to climb, a wood to help you cross a cliff, or a vacuum to suck your enemy. Not only that, you need to think by observing the level first before proceeding, simply because one wrong move and you need to rewind. What a way to sharpen your logic and decision making ability.

Fun little strategy game. Worth 50 cents for certain. :)

reviewText:
Game: Toki Tori
Genre: Puzzle
Developer: Two Tribes
System: Steam (PC)
Total Score: 76/100
Value Score: 7.6/10

• Story: 3/10
o Toki Tori's storyline involves a little chick by the name of Toki Tori who must rescue his brothers and sisters after they were swept away to a dark castle. After he hatches from his eggshell he goes on a journey to save them.

• Characters: 7/10
o You have Toki Tori who pretty much has a nice personality for a character of a game that doesnt seem like it has much, his cute and hilarious appearances and actions will put you in high spirits even in times of frustration when trying to solve the puzzles in the game. Along with that you have the enemies in the game which vary depending on the stages and offers a variety which has no clones at all which is nice.

• GamePlay: 10/10
o Toki Tori's gameplay involves mainly in a puzzle genre with some platforming abilities such as jumping and moving around in a 2D stage. You will get access to all sorts of abilities and items which can do anything ranging from teleporting, freezing enemies, providing you cover or a path to a certain area which you couldnt do before. There are also different obstacles and enemies which will be in your way which you can pass through using various methods. Your goal in the game is to collect all of the eggs in the level. By collecting all the eggs completely you will go to the next stage within the level which offers a whole different layout with new obstacles and enemy placement. You will be limited to certain items with certain amounts as well. There will be times when you make a mistake and you can undo this by rewinding or even forwarding if you undo a rewind - this is very useful as you will tend to make more mistakes as you progress through the game as the puzzles and layouts get more complex.

• Graphics: 8/10
o The visuals have improved quite well from the GBC version of the game, the game is in HD and the animations are quite nicely done. The environment and levels are well designed as well. Visuals are spot on in terms of quality however there will be times where you might see a glitch but the chances of that happening are pretty slim. Although the visuals are nicely done the backgrounds however could of had more work on it - the obstacles and the objects which you interact with were the ones which were mostly focused on.

• Sound: 8/10
o Toki Tori's sound effects go well with all the events in the game from walking, jumping and attacking a enemy. The sound effects are nicely done although there can be at times when the game may and can be seem to be too quiet.

• Music: 7/10
o The music is quite well done in Toki Tori, each set of stages have their own theme music, you have the main theme song and the credits. Although its OST isnt as huge as other games - it has a pretty decent variation of different types of songs.

• Length: 5/10
o Toki Tori's main fault is possibly its length, the main storyline will take you no more than 3 hours if you know exactly what you are doing, there will be at some points where you may get stuck and may take you some time in the game however if you are looking for a long term experience - it might not be the best option for you unless you do the extra stages and re-do the main storyline in the harder difficulty.

• Replay Value: 10/10
o The game includes a whole new difficulty setting for the main storyline along with some new additional custom stages and a campaign which spins off from Portal 2. The bonus levels and the extra difficulty makes up for the replay department for Toki Tori and is heavily recommended.

• Player Value: 8/10
o Toki Tori is a short and sweet game for those who love puzzles and a bright colored atmospheric game. The game's puzzles will leave you thinking on how to progress and the colorful themes in the design and music will keep you on your way as you try to solve through the puzzles in the game. The game comes with about 4 worlds with a set number of stages and the PC version includes additional bonus levels and a rewind/forward button feature which allows you to undo mistakes.

It’s sort of like Lemmings but instead of having a bunch of lemmings walking to their death unless you tell them to use the tools, you have Toki Tori who doesn’t even move unless you tell him to. You still get (usually) limited amounts of each tool, but instead of waiting for the flow of lemmings to get to where you want the tool used, you just need to get Toki Tori there.\n\nToki Tori is a fun little distraction. If you're looking for a genuinely challenging game of good, clean, puzzle-solving, and no less than roughly a dozen hours worth of play before completion, I sincerely recommend 'Toki Tori.'

In 'Toki Tori,' you play a fun-sized, flightless-jumpless bird, collecting eggs by navigating around platforms, and dodging enemies, utilizing your array of tools to your advantage. The challenge is that not all the tools are available at once, and they have a limited amount of uses, pre-set specifically per level. This knowledge provides clues to achieving your goal, placing you in a sport of trial-and-error until you find a way that works for you.

If practicing puzzles isn't your cup of tea, there isn't much I can recommend here. The game can get slow and sluggish; as more elements get added to levels, the possibilities expand, and you must keep trying similar things in various combinations until you find one that works. If you're akin to puzzle-style experimentation, you've got no problem, because the higher levels especially require tons of patience before you figure out what to do.

The art style of the game is cozily cartoonish; the physical setting and music of changes per level, which doesn't necessarily add to the gameplay, but rather to its warm and friendly vibe. A great (and my favorite) aspect in this game is the Rewind button, allowing you to carefully step back in order to do an alternative action without having to respawn. This makes learning the levels more hands-on, as you can explore a potentially incorrect move without the fear of it breaking your success so far. Furthermore, since there's no time limit, you're free to scout and plan without being pressured.

To label 'Toki Tori' as a simple kid's game (I've seen people do it) is a great injustice to the hours of gruelling, mind-mastering required to be victorious. This game makes me feel SO fulfilled and smart when I figure out how to finish a level. While I consider myself an experienced puzzle gamer, 9 hours in and I've yet to finish Normal mode, and there's still Hard and Bonus to go.

As a whole, there's not a lot of replayability here; once you've done all the modes, it's simply a nice trophy for your achievement cabinet. However, with over 80 levels, and greatly increasing difficulty, a substantial amount of commitment is required to finish the game on your own (No walkthroughs! Like a true puzzle solver!) If you like a cute, quality game that exercises your brain, I say get 'Toki Tori' and experience it for yourself.

If you're looking for a genuinely challenging game of good, clean, puzzle-solving, and no less than roughly a dozen hours worth of play before completion, I sincerely recommend 'Toki Tori.'

In 'Toki Tori,' you play a fun-sized, flightless-jumpless bird, collecting eggs by navigating around platforms, and dodging enemies, utilizing your array of tools to your advantage. The challenge is that not all the tools are available at once, and they have a limited amount of uses, pre-set specifically per level. This knowledge provides clues to achieving your goal, placing you in a sport of trial-and-error until you find a way that works for you.

If practicing puzzles isn't your cup of tea, there isn't much I can recommend here. The game can get slow and sluggish; as more elements get added to levels, the possibilities expand, and you must keep trying similar things in various combinations until you find one that works. If you're akin to puzzle-style experimentation, you've got no problem, because the higher levels especially require tons of patience before you figure out what to do.

The art style of the game is cozily cartoonish; the physical setting and music of changes per level, which doesn't necessarily add to the gameplay, but rather to its warm and friendly vibe. A great (and my favorite) aspect in this game is the Rewind button, allowing you to carefully step back in order to do an alternative action without having to respawn. This makes learning the levels more hands-on, as you can explore a potentially incorrect move without the fear of it breaking your success so far. Furthermore, since there's no time limit, you're free to scout and plan without being pressured.

To label 'Toki Tori' as a simple kid's game (I've seen people do it) is a great injustice to the hours of gruelling, mind-mastering required to be victorious. This game makes me feel SO fulfilled and smart when I figure out how to finish a level. While I consider myself an experienced puzzle gamer, 9 hours in and I've yet to finish Normal mode, and there's still Hard and Bonus to go.

As a whole, there's not a lot of replayability here; once you've done all the modes, it's simply a nice trophy for your achievement cabinet. However, with over 80 levels, and greatly increasing difficulty, a substantial amount of commitment is required to finish the game on your own (No walkthroughs! Like a true puzzle solver!) If you like a cute, quality game that exercises your brain, I say get 'Toki Tori' and experience it for yourself.

Great remake of a forgotten gem of a game for the Game Boy. (Bet you didn't know this was originally a Game Boy game, didn't you?)

Pros:
+ Puzzle-based gameplay that manages to be fun and challenging without being too frustrating
+ Rewind feature - No matter how badly you mess up, you can still save yourself
+ Improved/simplified controls from the original Game Boy version
+ Play w/ keyboard, mouse, or controller (whichever suits you)
+ Nice graphics
+ Level editor
+ Easy to mod

Cons:
- Banner ad for Toki Tori 2+ on title screen
- New soundtrack isn't as good as the soundtrack from the original Game Boy version
- Doesn't work on OS X El Capitan at the moment

I give this game an 8 out of 10. If you get the chance, I would definitely recommend giving this game a try.
